questions.text: Which type of cancer won't be affected if a patient uses OCP, which is a protective factor for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Endometrial cancer

  • OCPs have been associated with a reduced risk of endometrial (uterine) cancer. The hormones in OCPs help regulate the menstrual cycle and decrease the exposure of the endometrial lining to excessive amounts of estrogen, which can contribute to the development of endometrial cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Cervical cancer

  • OCP use does not directly affect the risk of cervical cancer. However, regular Pap smears and human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination are effective preventive measures against cervical cancer.

Option C: Breast cancer

  • The relationship between OCP use and breast cancer risk is complex. Some studies have shown a slight increase in the risk of breast cancer among current and recent OCP users, particularly in younger women. However, the risk seems to decrease after discontinuation of OCP use. The overall impact on breast cancer risk is relatively small.

Option D: Bladder cancer

  • OCP use is not known to have a significant effect on bladder cancer risk. Bladder cancer risk factors are more closely related to tobacco use, exposure to certain chemicals, and chronic bladder irritation.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the use of an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) absolutely contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. HIV infection

Explanation:

  • Among the listed options, the absolute contraindication for IUCD use is active, untreated HIV infection with immunosuppression and high risk of pelvic infections. In such cases, IUCD insertion can increase the chance of ascending infection and sepsis.
  • Controlled hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus are not absolute contraindications- though they may be considered for caution depending on the patient’s overall health and choice of contraceptive method.
  • Conditions where IUCD use poses unacceptable health risks, as per WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) Category 4.

Absolute Contraindications:

  • Current PID or purulent cervicitis.
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding.
  • Known or suspected pregnancy.
  • Cervical or endometrial cancer.
  • Distorted uterine cavity (e.g., large fibroids).
  • Active, untreated HIV infection with high risk of opportunistic infections.

Safer Alternatives in HIV:

  • Condoms (dual protection).
  • Hormonal methods (with drug–drug interaction checks).

Condition

Category

Remarks

Active HIV with AIDS symptoms

4

Absolute contraindication

HIV on ART, clinically stable

2

Benefits outweigh risks

Unexplained vaginal bleeding

4

Insert only after evaluation

Current PID

4

Treat infection before IUCD insertion

Hypertension (Option A) – Not an absolute contraindication; copper IUCDs can be used safely.

Hyperlipidemia (Option B) – No restriction for IUCD use.

Diabetes mellitus (Option C) – Not an absolute contraindication; copper IUCDs are generally safe unless there is severe infection risk or uncontrolled complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the scope of modern family planning services?
questions.solution:
Correct Ans. C

  • Not Providing adoption services is incorrect as adoption services are provided in modern concept of family planning services.

Incorrect Option: 

Option A.Proper spacing and limiting childbirth: It is a part of the modern concept of family planning services.

Option B. Genetic counseling: It is a part of the modern concept of family planning services.

Option D. Education on parenthood: It is a part of the modern concept of family planning services.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the given image is not true?

choices.text: It is inserted by withdrawal technique
The copper in this device has a surface area of 380 square mm
It has a life-span of 5 years
It is used in emergency contraception

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C) It has a life-span of 5 years

Explanation:

  • The image depicts CuT 380. Copper T is designed to provide contraception for an extended period. Depending on the specific type of Copper T used, it typically has a lifespan of 10 years for CuT380A.

2nd generation IUDs

Type

Copper containing device

Mechanism of action
  • Reduces sperm motility and survival
    • alters cervical mucus
    • affects uterine enzymes
    • increases cellular response in endometrium

Features
  • Strong anti-fertility effect
  • Low expulsion rate
  • Easy to fit in nulliparous women
  • Lesser side effects
  • Effective post-coital contraceptive (Option D ruled out)

Side effects
  • Bleeding
  • Pain
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine perforation
  • Failure of contraception ➜ Pregnancy
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Expulsion
  • Migration of IUD

Insertion technique

Withdrawl technique (Option A ruled out)

CuT 380A
  • 380 mm² of copper wire around a stem with nylon thread attached (Option B ruled out)
  • Shelf life -10 years (Option C)

Nova-T
  • CuT 380 A with a silver (Ag) core attached to it
  • Shelf life - 5 years

Multiload
  • U-shaped ring
  • Most commonly used IUD
  • CuT 375

questions.text: A couple approaches the doctor with a query regarding sexual precautions following the male partner's vasectomy procedure conducted a month ago. What guidance should be provided in this situation?

choices.text: Oral contraceptive pills for 1 month for the woman
Hormonal treatment given for 2 more months for the man

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option B: Use condoms for 3 months

Explanation:

  • After a vasectomy, it is important to provide appropriate advice to the couple regarding contraception. Using condoms for 3 months helps to ensure that any remaining sperm are cleared and reduces the risk of unintended pregnancy during this period.
  • After 3 months, the couple may choose to rely solely on the vasectomy as a contraceptive method. However, it is important to note that a follow-up semen analysis should be performed to confirm the success of the procedure and the absence of sperm in the ejaculate.

Vasectomy is a terminal method of contraception done in males. It is a single time method, which does not require prolonged motivation for its effectiveness.

Guidelines for Vasectomy:

  • The age of the husband should be 25-50 yrs.
  • The couple should have 2 living children.
  • If the couple has 3 or more children, then the lower limit of age can be relaxed.

Procedure:

Postoperative advice:

  • Must use alternate methods of contraception for 30 ejaculations (roughly 3 months) after the procedure to ensure sterility (option B).
  • Should keep the surgical area clean
  • Should not lift weights

questions.text: What is the most frequent side effect experienced by a 24-year-old woman of reproductive age who visited a rural primary healthcare center in India for the purpose of having an IUCD inserted to prevent pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option D: Bleeding

Explanation:

  • The most common side effect of IUCD insertion is increased or irregular menstrual bleeding. Women may experience heavier or longer periods, spotting between periods, or irregular bleeding patterns in the initial months after IUCD insertion. This is a common and expected side effect that usually resolves over time.

Side effects of IUDs

Bleeding (Option D)
  • Most common side effect; physiological bleeding resolves in 1-3 months. Iron supplementation may be needed.
  • Persistent bleeding despite treatment may necessitate IUD removal.

Pain (Option C ruled out)

Frequently causes removal; managed with analgesics. Resolves in 3 months. Severe pain may indicate uterine perforation (rare).

Pelvic inflammatory disease (OptionB ruled out)

Certain organisms reach the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries via the IUD thread. Presents with fever, abdominal pain, and discharge. Higher risk in women with multiple sexual partners. Requires broad-spectrum antibiotics; IUD removal if no improvement.

Uterine perforation

Rare complications linked to immediate postpartum insertion or poor technique. 1st generation IUDs are associated with a higher risk of pregnancy.

Failure of contraception ➜ pregnancy
  • Least pregnancies are reported with MIRENA.
  • If a woman requests an induced abortion – legally allowed.
  • If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are visible:
    • Pull the thread and continue pregnancy.
    • Explain the risk of spontaneous abortion or congenital anomalies.
  • If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are not visible:
    • Uterus examination for any complications
    • Evacuation of uterus if any complication is identified.

Ectopic pregnancy (OPTION A ruled out)

Recognized by lower abdominal pain, dark vaginal bleeding, or amenorrhea. Women at high risk should avoid IUDs.

Expulsion

Typically occurs within weeks of insertion or during menstruation; higher risk in young, nulliparous, postpartum women or using 1st generation IUDs

Migration of IUD

Rarely causes intestinal obstruction; diagnosed via X-ray imaging if suspected.

questions.text: A 25 year old female is using vaginal sponge as a barrier contraceptive during sexual intercourse. Which of the following Spermicide is used in contraceptive 'TODAY'?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - Option C) Nonoxynol-9

Explanation:

Nonoxynol-9 is a commonly used spermicide that is used as the active ingredient in many barrier contraceptives, including vaginal sponges, foams, gels, and creams. It works by immobilizing and killing sperm, thus reducing the risk of pregnancy. Nonoxynol-9 is the spermicide used in the contraceptive product 'TODAY'.

 

Brand name

TODAY

Material

Small polyurethane foam sponge

Mechanism of action

Combines barrier and spermicidal methods to prevent conception Saturated with 1000 mg of spermicide ‘Non-oxynol-9’ (Option C)

Technique of use
  • Must be run under water till thoroughly wet before insertion
  • Inserted vaginally and must be ‘placed over the cervix to be effective
  • Must be left in place for 6 hours after ejaculation
  • All sponges must be removed within the time limits specified by the manufacturer (24 hours for Today)

Disadvantages
  • No protection from HIV or STDs
  • May lead to Toxic Shock Syndrome if left beyond 24 hours
  • Has to be left for 6 hours post ejaculation
  • Increased risk of yeast infection and UTI
  • Higher failure rate than diaphragm

Failure rate
  • Parous women: 20-40 per HWY
  • Nulliparous women: 9-20 per HWY

Incorrect Options:

NET-EN (Option A): NET-EN stands for norethisterone enanthate, which is a progestin hormone used in some hormonal contraceptives, such as injectable contraceptives. It is not the spermicide used in the contraceptive product 'TODAY.

DMPA (Option B): DMPA stands for depot medroxyprogesterone acetate, which is another progestin hormone used in injectable contraceptives, commonly known as the birth control shot. It is not the spermicide used in the contraceptive product 'TODAY'.

Norethisterone (Option D): Norethisterone is a progestin hormone used in some hormonal contraceptives, such as combined oral contraceptives (COCs) or progestin-only pills (mini-pills). It is not the spermicide used in the contraceptive product 'TODAY'.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for the device shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Vaginal bleeding

  • The given image is of Copper T, an Intrauterine contraceptive device (IUDs).
  • Vaginal bleeding is an absolute contraindication for the use of IUDs

Contraindications to IUD insertion:

  • Absolute C/I:
    • Suspected pregnancy
    • CA cervix, uterus, adnexa other pelvic tumours
    • PID (active)
    • Vaginal bleeding of unknown cause
    • Previously diagnosed ectopic pregnancy
  • Relative C/I:
    • Anemia (OPTION A)
    • Menorrhagia
    • PID previously diagnosed
    • Purulent discharge
    • Uterine cavity distortion (fibroid, congenital malformations) (Options C, D)

questions.text: The duration for which copper T 380 A remains effective is referred to as its shelf life.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 10 years

Explanation:

  • Copper T 380 A is a long-term contraceptive device that remains effective for up to 10 years after insertion, making it a widely used option for long-term family planning.

 

3 years (Option A): is incorrect because copper T 380 A is designed for long-term contraception, far exceeding a 3-year effectiveness duration.

5 years (Option B): is incorrect because copper T 380 A provides contraceptive protection well beyond five years, although some other intrauterine devices have a 5-year lifespan.

7 years (Option C): is incorrect because copper T 380 A's effective duration is specifically rated for up to 10 years by manufacturers and health guidelines.

questions.text: All are given as emergency contraceptives except:

choices.text: OCP 2 tab within 24 hrs, repeat dose after 14 days

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - OCP 2 tab within 24 hrs, repeat dose after 14 days:

  • This option refers to using regular combined oral contraceptive pills (birth control pills) as an emergency contraceptive. While some regular birth control pills can be used as emergency contraception, the regimen described here is not a recommended or standard approach. Emergency contraception should involve specific doses of emergency contraceptive pills (like levonorgestrel or ulipristal) taken within the specified time frame. Regular birth control pills taken in this manner may not provide the same level of effectiveness as dedicated emergency contraceptive pills. Therefore, this option is not a recommended method of emergency contraception.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - LNG 0.75 mg 2 tab: LNG (Levonorgestrel) is a progestin-only emergency contraceptive pill commonly known as the "morning-after pill" or "Plan B." It is effective at preventing pregnancy when taken within a specific time frame after unprotected intercourse. The correct dosage is to take 1.5 mg of LNG (either as a single 1.5 mg tablet or two 0.75 mg tablets) as soon as possible after unprotected intercourse. This option is indeed an emergency contraceptive.

Option B - Ethinylestradiol tablet: Ethinylestradiol is a synthetic form of the hormone estrogen, and it is commonly used in combination with progestin as a component of oral contraceptive pills (birth control pills).

Option C - Ulipristal T: Ulipristal acetate is a selective progesterone receptor modulator that is used as an emergency contraceptive. It can be taken up to 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected intercourse and is more effective than levonorgestrel when taken closer to the end of the recommended time frame. So, option C is indeed an emergency contraceptive.

questions.text: A female presents at 22 weeks of pregnancy due to rape. Which statement is correct regarding medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)?

choices.text: Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor’s opinion is required
Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother
MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case
MTP can be done after 24 weeks.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case:

  • MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case:
    • According to the amended MTP Act, 2021, MTP is permitted up to 24 weeks in cases of rape, with the opinion of two doctors.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor’s opinion is required: Under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, for pregnancies between 20-24 weeks, the opinion of two doctors is required, not just one. This applies to specific categories, including survivors of sexual assault.

Option B - Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother: While protecting the life of the mother is one consideration, MTP can also be performed during this period for other reasons, including if the pregnancy is a result of rape, or if there are significant fetal anomalies, without the need for the condition to be life-threatening to the mother.

Option D - MTP can be done after 24 weeks: MTP beyond 24 weeks is generally not permitted unless severe fetal anomalies are detected that are incompatible with life, or if there is a threat to the mother's life or health. This requires the approval of a medical board.

Correct option:

Option B: Nonoxynol-9

Nonoxynol-9 is a spermicidal agent commonly used in contraceptive methods. It is a surfactant that works by disrupting the cell membranes of sperm, thereby immobilizing and killing them. It is available in various forms such as creams, gels, foams, and suppositories. Nonoxynol-9 is typically applied directly to the cervix or inserted into the vagina before intercourse to provide contraception.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Gossypol- Gossypol is a natural compound derived from the cotton plant. While it has been studied for its potential contraceptive properties, it is not commonly used as a spermicidal cream. Gossypol's main use in contraception research has been focused on its effects on male fertility by inhibiting sperm production. However, its use as a contraceptive method is still under investigation and not widely available.

Option C: Centchroman- Centchroman, also known as oral contraceptive pill (OCP) or Saheli, is an oral contraceptive medication. It is a non-hormonal selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that inhibits ovulation, alters the endometrium, and suppresses sperm motility. It is taken orally as a tablet and not used as a spermicidal cream.

Option D: Clomiphene- Clomiphene is a medication commonly used in fertility treatment. It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that acts by stimulating the release of hormones necessary for ovulation. While it is involved in the process of enhancing fertility, it is not a spermicidal cream and is not used for contraception purposes.

choices.text: Currently married couple where the wife is in reproductive age (15-49 yr. of age)
Eligible couples who have 2 – 3 living children

questions.solution:
Correct option B: Eligible couples who have 2 – 3 living children

  • Term target couples is applied to couples who have 2-3 living children or even newly married couples to make them accept the idea of family planning.

Incorrect Options

Option A.  "Currently married couple where the wife is in reproductive age (15-49 yr. of age)," is definition of eligible couple.

Option C. "Couple using contraception," refers to couples who are already using some form of contraception. While they are part of the target population for monitoring and evaluation of family planning services, the term "target couple" generally encompasses a broader group of couples who are eligible for family planning, including those not currently using contraception.

Option D. "Couple with 3 children," does not accurately capture the definition of a target couple. The number of children a couple has does not determine their eligibility or need for family planning services. Family planning aims to provide individuals and couples with the information, services, and methods to plan and space their pregnancies according to their desires and circumstances.

questions.text: Which contraceptive method should not be used in cases of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: OCP

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a condition characterized by the formation of blood clots in deep veins, usually in the legs. Certain contraceptives can increase the risk of developing DVT. These contraceptives contain hormones, such as estrogen and progestin, which can affect blood coagulation and increase the risk of blood clot formation.

Oral contraceptive pills (OCP): Oral contraceptive pills contain hormones, including estrogen and progestin. Estrogen, in particular, is associated with an increased risk of blood clot formation. Therefore, OCPs are contraindicated in individuals with a history of DVT or those at high risk of developing blood clots.

Contraindications of OCP:

  • Absolute:
    • Cancer of the breast and genitals
    • Liver disease
    • Previous or present history of thromboembolism
    • Cardiac abnormalities
    • Congenital hyperlipidaemia
    • Undiagnosed Abnormal uterine bleeding
  • Relative: (Special problems requiring medical surveillance)
    • Age over 40 years, or Smoking, and age over 35 years
      • Risk of cardiovascular ffects increases with age and smoking.
      • Go for progesterone-only pills.
      • If she is a smoker, don't give combined pills if her age is over 35 years.
    • Mild hypertension
    • Chronic renal disease
    • Epilepsy
    • Migraine
    • Nursing mothers in the first 6 months
    • Diabetes Mellitus
    • Gallbladder disease
    • History of infrequent bleeding
    • Amenorrhea, etc

Incorrect options:

Option A: IUD (Intrauterine device): The use of an IUD is not contraindicated in individuals with a history of DVT. IUDs do not contain hormones that affect blood coagulation.

Option B: Condoms: Condoms are a barrier method of contraception and do not contain hormones. They do not increase the risk of DVT.

Option D: No C/l (No contraindications): This option is incorrect because certain contraceptives, specifically those containing hormones, can indeed be contraindicated in individuals with a history of DVT or those at high risk.

questions.text: What are the absolute contraindications for intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs)?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Acute PID

  • Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) are a highly effective form of long-acting reversible contraception. While IUCDs are generally safe and well-tolerated, there are certain situations where they are contraindicated due to potential risks and complications.
  • Acute PID (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease): Acute PID is an absolute contraindication for the insertion of an IUCD. PID is an infection of the reproductive organs, and the presence of an IUCD can potentially worsen the infection, increase the risk of complications, and delay appropriate treatment.
Absolute Relative 
Pregnancy Anemia, Menorrhagia 
Recurrent PID History of PID 
Vaginal discharge of undiagnosed etiology  Purulent cervical discharge 
Cancer of cervix, uterus or adnexa  Distortion of uterine cavities e.g., congenital malformations, fibroids 
Previous ectopic pregnancy  Unmotivated person 

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Anaemia: Anaemia is not an absolute contraindication for the use of an IUCD. It may be a relative contraindication if the anaemia is severe and associated with significant symptoms, but it does not pose a direct risk for IUCD insertion or use.

Option B: DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis): DVT is not an absolute contraindication for IUCD use. DVT is primarily a concern with hormonal methods of contraception, such as combined oral contraceptives, due to the increased risk of blood clot formation. IUCDs, which do not contain hormones, do not have the same associated risk of DVT.

Option D: Endometriosis: Endometriosis is not an absolute contraindication for IUCD use. While it may cause symptoms and discomfort, it does not directly contraindicate the use of an IUCD. The choice of contraception in individuals with endometriosis may depend on various factors and should be discussed with a healthcare provider.

questions.text: The most suitable contraceptive recommendation for a recently married couple is:
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: OCPs

  • When providing contraceptive advice to a newly married couple, several factors need to be considered, including effectiveness, convenience, safety, and personal preferences. While the choice ultimately depends on the couple's specific needs and circumstances, oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are often a suitable option for many couples.
  • OCPs (Oral Contraceptive Pills): OCPs are a highly effective form of contraception when used correctly. They provide reliable pregnancy prevention, are convenient to use, and have additional benefits such as regulating menstrual cycles, reducing menstrual pain, and improving acne. OCPs can be started immediately and discontinued when the couple decides to conceive.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Condoms: Condoms are a barrier method of contraception that provide protection against both unintended pregnancies and sexually transmitted infections (STIs). They are easily accessible, affordable, and do not require a prescription. Condoms can be a good option for couples who prefer non-hormonal methods or need STI protection in addition to contraception. However, they may have a higher failure rate compared to hormonal methods like OCPs.

Option C: Sterilization: Sterilization, such as tubal ligation for women or vasectomy for men, is a permanent method of contraception. It is considered a long-term and highly effective option for couples who have completed their desired family size or do not wish to have biological children. Sterilization should be approached as a permanent decision, as reversal procedures are costly and not always successful.

Option D: IUD (Intrauterine Device): IUDs are long-acting reversible contraceptives that offer highly effective contraception for an extended period. They can be a suitable choice for couples who desire long-term contraception without the need for daily or frequent user involvement. However, IUDs require a healthcare provider's insertion, which may not be immediately accessible for a newly married couple.

questions.text: What should be the minimum rate of couple protection in order to achieve the demographic target of NRR = 1?  NRR: Net Reproduction Rate
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: 60%

This option correctly states that the couple protection rate should exceed 60% to achieve an NRR of 1. While the exact required rate may vary depending on other factors, a couple protection rate exceeding 60% is generally necessary to achieve replacement-level fertility and an NRR of 1.

  • NRR, or Net Reproduction Rate, is a measure used to estimate the average number of daughters that would be born to a woman over her lifetime, given the prevailing age-specific fertility rates. An NRR of 1 indicates that the population is replacing itself, with each generation being replaced by an equal number of offspring.
  • To achieve an NRR of 1, it is necessary to have a couple protection rate that exceeds a certain threshold. The couple protection rate refers to the percentage of couples using effective contraception to prevent pregnancy. The higher the couple protection rate, the more effectively pregnancies are prevented, leading to a lower total fertility rate and potentially achieving an NRR of 1.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 50%- This option suggests that a couple protection rate of 50% is required to reach an NRR of 1. However, this is not accurate. A couple protection rate of 50% might not be sufficient to achieve replacement-level fertility and an NRR of 1.

Option B: 40%- This option suggests that a couple protection rate of 40% is needed to reach an NRR of 1. However, this is not correct. A couple protection rate of 40% might still be insufficient to achieve the desired replacement-level fertility.

Option C: 70%- This option suggests that a couple protection rate of 70% is necessary to reach an NRR of 1. However, this is not accurate. While a higher couple protection rate increases the likelihood of achieving replacement-level fertility, a rate of 70% may be higher than what is required to reach an NRR of 1

questions.text: Which contraceptive method has the highest reported failure rate?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • The correct answer is "Spermicidal methods." Spermicidal methods, such as spermicide creams, gels, foams, or suppositories, have higher failure rates compared to other contraceptive methods. They are generally used in combination with barrier methods, such as condoms, to enhance effectiveness.

Incorrect option: 

Option B. Implant: Implants are highly effective long-acting reversible contraceptive methods and have a very low failure rate.

Option C. Oral contraceptive pills: Oral contraceptive pills, when used correctly, are highly effective in preventing pregnancy and have low failure rates.

Option D. IUD: Intrauterine devices (IUDs), both hormonal and non-hormonal, are highly effective contraceptive methods with very low failure rates.
